Content.Title: Q1/17 Moderately Better than Expected In Challenging Deflationary Environment

Data.TextElement: Overall, we would describe Loblaw's Q1/17 as positive, as it was moderately better than expected. We attribute the better-than-expected results to strong grocery performance, with slightly better-than-expected deflation and tonnage. In addition, retail gross margin and SG&A margin improved y/y (excluding the impact of franchise consolidation).

• On May 3, before the market open, Loblaw reported Q1/17 fully diluted adjusted earnings of $0.90, above our estimate and the Mean estimate, both of which were $0.87. Loblaw reported same-store sales (SSS) decline of 2.1%, however on an adjusted basis after considering to the timing of New Year's Day and Easter, SSS growth was flat y/y. With internal food deflation in line with the CPI of 3.9% deflation for the quarter, this implies reported tonnage growth of about 1.8%.
  • Shoppers reported overall SSS of 0.9%, with SSS of 2.5% on an adjusted basis, which was in line with our expectation for 2.8%. Adjusted pharmacy SSS of 1.4% (vs. BMO's 2.5%) was below our expectation. Adjusted front store SSS was slightly stronger than we had anticipated at 3.6% (vs. BMO's 3.0%).
  • Retail gross margin improved by 63 bps, better than our expectation for an improvement of 2 bps. Excluding the accounting impact from the consolidation of franchises, retail gross margin improved by 10 bps, versus our expectation for a deterioration of 20 bps.
  • Excluding the consolidation of franchises, SG&A margin improved 10 bps y/y, slightly worse than our expectation for an improvement of 20 bps. The y/y improvement was aided by the positive impact of store closures and favourable changes in the value of the franchise business. However, this was partially offset by the unfavourable timing of New Year’s Day and Easter in both Food and Drug retail.
  • Loblaw is continuing to call for positive SSS for 2017, suggesting that management anticipates continuing strong tonnage trends to offset the effect of food deflation.
  • See Page 2 for the historical valuation of the Canadian grocers' core retail businesses.
  • Conference call today at 10am ET; 647-427-7450 or 1-888-231-8191; Replay: 416-849-0833 or 1-855-859-2056 (Passcode: 1695648); Webcast here.
Data.BoilerPlate: We rate Loblaw shares Market Perform. We believe Loblaw continues to benefit from incremental synergies from the Shoppers Drug Mart acquisition, and operational improvements related to the completed implementation and optimization of the SAP system. However, the Canadian grocers are now in a deflationary environment that will pressure top-line growth and operating results.

Loblaw is currently valued at about 8.1x our 2017 EBITDAR estimate, after carving out the value attributable to the interest in Choice Properties REIT. This valuation is toward the high end of Loblaw's historical valuation, which has traditionally been within a range of 6.0-8.0x trailing EBITDAR (ex. Choice REIT).
Under the upside scenario, we would see a higher EBITDA growth rate of 7%. Applying a roughly 9x multiple to EBITDAR would result in an $81 share price.
Under the downside scenario, we would see a 5% decline in EBITDA y/y. Applying a 7x multiple to EBITDAR would result in a $57 share price.

Loblaw Companies Limited is the largest food retailer/wholesaler in Canada. It operates corporate stores and franchised or affiliated stores in all provinces. Banners include Loblaws, Fortinos, Zehrs Markets, Provigo, Maxi, The Atlantic Superstore, No Frills, The Real Canadian Superstore, and T&T. In March 2014, Loblaw acquired Shoppers Drug Mart.
Our target price is based on 8.1x our 2017 EBITDAR estimate, plus Loblaw’s interest in Choice Properties REIT.

The Canadian grocery industry is sensitive to a number of economic factors. In particular, declines in personal disposable income, food inflation/deflation, and appreciation of the Canadian dollar could have a negative impact on the industry’s revenues and profitability. Also, competitive pressures from existing Canadian food retailing competitors and potential new entrants could result in reduced revenues and margins. Labour disputes could present higher costs and business disruptions. Associated dealer relationships, if not maintained, could also subject the company to risk. The loss of key senior management could have an adverse effect on the company. Share declines at publicly traded Choice Properties REIT (CHP.UN, $13.90, Market Perform rated by Troy MacLean) could adversely affect Loblaw’s valuation.

Ratings Key (as of October 2016)

We use the following ratings system definitions:
OP = Outperform - Forecast to outperform the analyst’s coverage universe on a total return basis;
Mkt = Market Perform - Forecast to perform roughly in line with the analyst’s coverage universe on a total return basis;
Und = Underperform - Forecast to underperform the analyst’s coverage universe on a total return basis;
(S) = Speculative investment;
Spd = Suspended - Coverage and rating suspended until coverage is reinstated;
NR = No Rated - No rating at this time; and
R = Restricted - Dissemination of research is currently restricted.

BMO Capital Markets' seven Top 15 lists guide investors to our best ideas according to different objectives (CDN Large Cap, CDN Small Cap, US Large Cap, US Small Cap, Income, CDN Quant, and US Quant have replaced the Top Pick rating).

FCA regulations require that a firm providing research disclose its ownership interest in the issuer that is the subject of the research if it and its affiliates own 5% or more of the equity of the issuer. Canadian regulations require that a firm providing research disclose its ownership interest in the issuer that is the subject of the research if it and its affiliates own 1% or more of the equity of the issuer that is the subject of the research.
